[Characters]: (10/10) (SPOILERS)

"I want something genuine" -Hikigaya Hachiman


Never before has an anime made me want these characters to not get together but at the same time making me want to see them get together. Sounds confusing? Let me explain and I did put a "Spoilers" tag so here's the spoiler.


At the end, there was one scene where Yuki and Yui started noticing or have already noticed their feelings towards Hiki. If one of them reveals their feelings to Hachiman then the friendship between these 3 characters might or will most likely fall apart. What if Yui and Hiki got together? What will happen to Yukino? She's already in a terrible state. Let's say the situation is flipped around, what will happen to Yui? It will just end up in a love triangle. There's also the fact that Hachiman might have "feelings" for Yukino based on what I've seen on the second half of this season. If that is true then what's going to happen to Yui?  Either way, their friendship is f*cked unless Yukino is happy with Hiki and Yui's new relationship and vice versa or they could try polygamy. I need to kill myself just for suggesting the latter option. I really don't want to see their current relationship to fall apart. On the other hand, I signed up expecting Romance and by god's name they will give me goddamn Romance. 


What makes this so different from other love triangles out there that you mainly see in Romantic Comedies? This scene was a lot more realistic in terms of potential love triangle that could break their friendship apart. Just look at the ending episode again..Yui didn't want to confess her feelings to Hiki immediately because she cared for Yukino's feelings. But if Yukino doesn't make a choice then she will make a move on Hikki. Yukino's feelings was taken in for consideration but at the same time, she didn't want to give up her own feelings or else she might regret it later on. When was the last time you see a character doing that sh*t?


In most Rom-Coms out there, the best girl always wins and the "third wheel" girl always and I mean ALWAYS gives up her own feelings just so the "man of her dreams" and the "best girl" can get together. It's predictable and that's not how it always works in real life. That "third wheel" girl can't just give up on her feelings that easily. You finally met the man of your dreams and you're just going to give it up to some girl you probably don't even like?! It's like the "third wheel" female character's feelings wasn't taken into consideration and she's just like "Oh, you can take my prince charming anytime..I'm cool with it". Bitch, you're not and you need to stop lying to yourself. Anyways....

In SNAFU's case, it's unpredictable. To this day, I still have no idea whether Hiki will pick Yui or Yukino.  


Now this is what you call a developed characters. I mean, the characters were already developed in the first season but the second season further developed these characters making me want to care for these people's relationship. Most noticeably is Hiki, Yui, Yukino and most of the side characters in the show. Hell, even Ebina..one of the most useless side characters (and also extremely funny) got a development in this season and it was a good one. I'm talking about Ebina's true personality and why she doesn't date boys. 


I really want to talk about the character progression from first season up to the last episode of the second season. The progression was like an immature bully kid to a grown man who now works at a Children's Aid. Just compare Hikki from the first season and this season. It's like night and day. The guy hated everyone, including Yukino and now he pretty much sacrifices himself for the good of the others and he also cares for Yukino and Yui. It's the same case for Yukino and Yui. I'm not going to provide examples for Yukino and Yui's progression because you get my point. 


One last thing that I want to talk about are the new characters introduced for this season. First is Iroha Ishiki...She is one of my new favourite characters in the series because of the way she acts. She's like a hybrid of Hikigaya Hachiman. She maintains a cute appearance and has an image of an "innocent girl" but on the inside, she's a rotten girl. She doesn't care what other people think of her except her appearance. I also love the running gag between Hiki and Ishiki where Ishiki keeps rejecting Hiki...as a joke, of course. One more character that I want to talk about is Kaori Orimoto..All you need to know about her is she's a Class A scumbag. However, there is no other girls that's worse than her other than Haruno, a Class S bitch that deserves to be hanged on a public street.

***This is a spoiler free review***
With the total failure of Date a Live and utter disappointment of Suisei no Gargantia, it’s a good thing there were other decent shows. While I lost interest in Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Come wa Machigatteiru in the middle of its airing, the amazing cast really brought this anime home.
Story: 5/10
So while the premise of the show really interested me, most of the content was just boring in my honest opinion. The show follows Hachiman, Yukino, and later on Yui as they help fellow classmates with their problems. While the cast interactions really made this show work, I wasunfortunately just bored with what was going on. Essentially Hachiman and Yukino are somewhat reserved people who kind of have to be forced into situations in order to open up at all. This provides some really interesting banter between them but I did not like how other characters in the anime looked down on them. On the socially opposite side of the high school spectrum, you had the “cool” kids headed by Hayato and Yumiko who I despised immensely.


In pertaining to the actual plot of the anime, essentially it boils down to the club Hachiman is part of taking on different tasks set forth either by fellow classmates or the club monitor Shizuka. While some interesting moments come up in the show, it was overall pretty boring and average stuff. The final episode was pretty interesting and enjoying but overall the whole show just really felt like clever conversations with blandness in between.


Animation: 7.1/10


So the animation quality was entirely dependent on which ever character was on the screen. While the animation itself was fluid and good, the quality of each character was not. Characters Yukino, Shizuka, Haruno, Saika (I don’t care if he is a trap), and some others had great character models and looked great while on screen. Hachiman and Yui though each had certain things I completely disliked and was annoyed by. Hachiman had a very fish like appearance (which was probably on purpose but I still didn’t like it) and I found that in a lot of scenes his character didn’t animate as fluid as the others. Yui while very pretty in appearance had some serious hair issues. This might be an extremely superficial gripe but there was just no detail to her hair; it just looked like a mangled knot.


Sound: 8/10


The voice actors deserve a 10/10 but the generic soundtrack really brought this anime down quite a bit. Starting with the bad, the soundtrack really just felt out of place and not adding what so ever to the anime. It was just uneventful and average at best. Now for the good; like for all the –monogatari series, dialogue plays a huge role in this anime. The back and forth bantering between characters was very well done and the voice actors did an excellent job. Both Hachiman and Yukino were awesome from episode 1-13.


Characters: 10/10


Hands down the best cast of this season and possibly last year as well. Both this show and Hentai Ouji to Warawanai Neko had really well knit characters that made whatever was going on extremely funny and/or interesting. In Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Come wa Machigatteiru the stars of the show was Hachiman and Yukino. Every single conversation that was focused on them was either funny, interesting, exciting, and/or cute. Hachiman while not a very interesting person to begin with was a pretty good male lead. He worked well with all the characters including the super cute and super trap Saika. He really made whatever situation the team was in better due to his “unique” insight. Yui (while a complete ditz) had a pretty big heart and served as a medium between the club and the “cool” kids. The club teacher Shizuka also had a huge impact on how the show turned out. Her constant meddling provided most of the situations the club got into.


The cast overall just felt so in-sync with each other. Even though some of the episodes really felt like there was no direction, the conversations between each character made it somewhat interesting.


Overall: 7.5/10


While boring in some parts, I have to recommend this anime to everyone looking for some laughs and enjoyment in the slice of life realm. The characters just make this show so interesting to watch and while the animation and sound isn’t overly great, they are good enough to help you enjoy what this anime has to offer.


Enjoyment: 6/10

9 all across the board, hey! What's not to like? Couple of characters you don't like? A little bit boring sometimes?
Character:
Very well developed. They're consistent in what they say and do, so by the end of it you have a very good feel of who they are and what they're like. Many of them harbor strange philosophies, but it should be remembered that these philosophies belong only to the characters, not the show. They change subtly at a micro level and drastically at a macro level, and it's quite nice to see these characters adapt themselves to the things and people that begin to surroundthem. 


Story:

Much more dramatic than the first season, be warned. It's still funny, but not as often and not as much. Things that have only just begun to simmer in season 1 will here burst to a boil. The story details the three main characters' relationships with each other and observes their slowly changing group dynamic. As you know, many of the characters in the series are very self aware about themselves and the rules governing their friendships, which adds an extra, very complicating dimension to the way in which they interact with one another. The story investigates what happens when these self-aware, awkward, philosophizing people begin to collide and form relationships. It's quite charming to watch. And above all, the show investigates this single question: what makes a relationship genuine?


Art:

Animation is a big step up from season 1, and the lighting adds so much to the show. People often underestimate the power of visuals, editing, pacing. This new art style and quality allows for so much depth of emotion. And the way the whole show is put together is enchanting. Time is given where time is required. There is a shot where the main character walks alongside a girl under the fading, egg-yolk sun, glowing just above the horizon. There's no swelling music or anything, just them walking. He reaches over and holds her grocery bags for her, and the whole thing takes perhaps 20 seconds, and I felt contentment just watching it. It's exactly the show it tries to be.


Sound:

Great voice acting, pleasant music. Fits the show perfectly.


Overall:

Fantastic show. It's deep, and it asks big questions not for the sake of asking them but in service of the characters. Everything is in service of the characters, and their changing eyes as they slowly adjust to the world around them. I really loved the show. For some reason I gave it an 8, because that's how it feels to me now, I'll probably change it to a 9 soon. Not only is the story great, the animation, the directing, the editing and sound -- it all fits together like pieces of a puzzle.

The continuation of Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Comedy wa Machigatteiru takes us further down the road of the struggles of our main character. Although it doesn't really provide anything new, it is still an enjoyable experience.
The story doesn't really progress a whole lot, which can be expected in an anime like this. Just like the first season, the plot is carried by the interesting characters. They are also basically the only reason this anime is worth a watch.
Other than that the art is pretty good and compliments the show rather well. The soundtrack is fairly forgetful however, although it does the job just fine.
Ifyou're expecting any real development of the story or a progression in the plot you will be somewhat disappointed, but the experience overall can still be rather enjoyable. If you enjoyed the first season, this season will most likely not disappoint.\n\n

SPOILERS AHEAD (sorta)
The second season practically screams - character development!!! When I think back on how the characters were on season 1, I can't even recognise them anymore.
For starters, Yukino Yukinoshita. In the season 1, she was an ice cold beauty blah blah blah, with literally no friends and bad past.
In season 2, she still has bad past and still is a beauty but now she has friends (and even the 'cool squad' - Hayama and Yumiko etc talks with her) and she even talks about herself - seems like Hikigaya and Yui have finally broken her shell... a little. She even starts showing atsundere side of her.

WHICH I DON'T REALLY LIKE. My opinion only but the 'real' Yukino sort of annoys me. In season 1 she was an interesting character with mysterious attitude (which she still has by the way) but now she's sorta... meh. Except for some weird moments (like Haruno pointing out that her 'trust' isn't trust at all).


Hikigaya has changed too. Like some people, I miss his 'lone wolf inner monologue' from season 1.  Even so, I am really happy for his character development. The thing I like the most is that now he's able to speak up when he thinks something is wrong. In season 1 we saw him struggling to stand up for his friends and himself... That has changed now.


As for Yui - she's my favorite character in the whole show. She's sort of the 'social glue' for the group and same as Hikigaya, she can finally speak up and help her friends not keep quiet. I especially love how she sort of proves (at least with her words) that she's not the 'nice girl' Hikigaya thought she was.


AS FOR MY MOST MOST FAVORITE CHARACTER IT'S OBVIOUSLY SHIZUKA HIRATSUKA. She's wise and cool and UGHHH her advives to Hikigaya and the way she looks out for the group just gets me everytime.


Liked the way Komachi became important in this season. While I'm on it, I seriously hate Isshiki. She's annoying and gets in the way and ugh.


---

As for the plot - it's no more a 'rom com'. I first got into this show while looking for rom coms. In the season one there was less rom and more com. In season 2 there's more tsundere rom and no com at all.

I loved the depth of the show and how it made me think. I lvoe that this show portrays completely realistic things and people and shows humans as they are - sometimes selfish, sometimes not, with a tendence to hurt each other and push others away. I think this show does a beautiful job of capturing ACTUAL reality and making you see it from different perspectieves. I won't lie saying that almost every episode made me cry.


---


One thing I definitely didn't enjoy was the art. Ok, now I finally understood why everyone is in love with Hikigaya - the new style really makes him sorta hot. As fo0r the rest, Yukino looked 'too nice' and those pink cheeks really pissed me of... But that's just my opinion.


---


Back to characters, I really love them all. This is one of few shows (actually only one so far) that show that 'popular guys' aren't all that bad. Yumiko, who has the 'classical bitch' atitude and looks is actually pretty nice. 

Hayama suprised me the most of them all. At season 1 I saw him as a douche and then he proved himself nice. At season 2 he proved that he's NOT NICE AT ALL but he's polite enough and HUMAN!!! His hate for Hikigaya isn't because Hikigaya is a loner or whatever, but because he feels inferior to him.

Ebina also proved herself as really nice, so did Tobe and well, you got it.


Anyway, THIS ENDED WITH A CLIFFHANGER AND I HATE CLIFFHANGERS. I really hope we get an season 3, because I really need that.

I am writing this review as part of my first anniversary in MyAnimelist.
MINOR SPOILERS
If you are reading this review and have already watched season 1, I advise that you skip to my scores and review.
If you are reading this review and you are looking for reviews into this series I advise that you should go and read reviews for the 1st season (which is great by the way). I will provide a light description for the series. It is about the anti-social high student, who became very against having friends because of social trauma and he creates his own ideology about everything. He questions aboutnormal things that young people do like hanging out with each other and just ENJOYING youth. It is the reverse of "Be yourself and society will accept you" and somewhat a deconstruction of harem.


Story: 10


As the word "outstanding" suggests the story in Zoku is very different than that of S1. In Zoku, it develops more of its side characters and develop what is really happening in the lives of our main characters. Like how you will know why Yukino is acting the way she does. The question that arises in Zoku penetrates deep into thought. It shows more empathetic and sympathetic views in the perspective of Hachiman. As for the flow of the story, it flows well after Hachiman's social suicide at the end of S1 and as the progress goes on we on the watcher's side learn more about the social environment we live in.


Art: 8


In Zoku the art was more consistent and shows more smoother flow in animation. Other than consistency the mood and the tone of the show was more favorable to the new character and background design. 


Sound: 8


The soundtrack was the same fluffy tune as it was in S1. No changes in there.


Character: 9


As I said in the story, the characters are more developed. However not all from the original source were used in the anime, some minor character development were omitted but don't worry about that since you can read the light novels soon. That's just the missing part of it.


Enjoyment: 10


For this part you may need to rewatch S1 read the Light Novels and somewhat intrigued by Hachiman's ideology. You may also somehow need to understand Hachiman's point of view and to learn why he does the things. Somehow understand the tropes and jokes Wataru Watari (the author) is throwing at you.


Overall: 9


This is a wonderful series and it is still needs to be finished. The show wants you to think about your social environment and also about the story. (that is at least for loners and for those who have friends as well) It greatly follows through what the 1st season had accomplished and really makes a great adaptation Light Novels.

My first review! (Please go easy on me >__Yui's confrontation with Hachiman and Yukino in the final episode. Even after the series, I did not have a very clear idea what the "genuine thing" Hachiman wanted was. I did not know if the author intended it to be this way, or if I missed something, but that was something that bothered me when I was watching this show. Other than that, I found the development of the story to be quite very enjoyable. My personal favourite part of the series was its use of dialogue and monologues to express the character's feelings and attitudes. Unlike many other series which bases its character relationships on friendship, many are which are quite superficial and phony, this series uses dialogue to analyse some of its more troubling aspects, along with themes of romance, dependency, and trust. The ending leaves the resolutions on an open note (in this case, a cliffhanger) which may leave many people dissatisfied. I can see why it is controversial, but in my opinion, I thought the ending concluded quite nicely. Even with some of its minor problems, the realism this show exhibits and the passion the characters have to struggle and understand these issues really pushes it above most other shows of this caliber and should be considered a sui generis masterpiece.


Art:


In the announcing of the new series, I was quite surprised by the change in animation studio, and was a bit apprehensive to see how the series would turn out. Since I really enjoyed season one's art (especially Hachiman's design), I didn't actually know if I would continue watching this season if the art didn't fit my tastes (and the storyline). When the show started, I had a hard time adjusting to the sudden change in character design, but over time it grew on me, so it wasn't too bad. The designs for the characters and background became more crisp, and the colouring became more sophisticated, with warmer colours used in more light hearted scenarios, and cooler colours used in the more melancholic moments (such as near the end of EP 7.)


Sound:


The series introduces a new opening and ending, both of which are honestly quite catchy and refreshing (I really like the song choices for this series; they are really nice to listen to). Also, the solo ballads sung by the voice actors for Yui and Yukino that replaced the endings were some of the most beautiful Japanese songs I have heard (why can't they get Hachiman's VA to do one too.... sigh). Most of the OST they used in the series are reused from the first season, which is nice because it helps the series retain the atmosphere that made Oregairu unique and enjoyable as a show. Also, as the series became more 'drama' driven than 'comedy' driven, the importance of the supporting background music also increased to intensify some of the more emotionally charged moments. I think the music was used very well in such situations, such as Hachiman's confessions about his feelings; the music really did help to amplify the emotional aspects of the scene.


Characters: 


In addition to the previous characters, the cast is also expanded to include many new ones, most notably the underclassman Isshiki Iroha, Orimoto, and the members of the partner school for the Christmas event. However, the main focus remains on the relationship between the three members of the Service Club, and how they overcome some of the more troubling obstacles in their relationship. 


Hikigaya Hachiman:


Our favourite misanthrope is back! Hachiman is one of my favourite characters in all the shows that I've seen In addition to his hilarious cynicism and pessimistic view on life, his observation skills and adept problem solving abilities really make him an enjoyable character to watch. When he is not in his antisocial mode, he plays the villain and is always ready to sacrifice himself for the sake of the wellbeing of his fellow classmates. His accomplishments usually goes unnoticed and he usually becomes the scapegoat, but he doesn't care as long as his objectives are met. In short words, he can be described as the kind of person who is indifferent to the process as long as he can reach the goal, even if it results in him hurting himself. What he doesn't realise is that as he strengthens his relationship with Yukino and Yui, his actions result in not only pain for himself, but also the pain in others. In Oregairu Zoku, Hachiman and his epiphany and the acknowledgement of his wrongs play a significant role in the progression of the story. Throughout the first part of the story and even in Season 1, Hiratsuka-sensei gave many warnings to Hachiman, saying that although his objectives are being met, his actions are hurting those around him. He notices that many of the actions he has taken are temporary and does not solve the problem at its roots. With the acknowledgement of wrongdoing and the struggle for change in EP. 8, Hachiman begins his search for something genuine. This serves as the turning point of the story and also the beginning of change in the four main characters. Hachiman serves as the catalyst for this change, and his willingness to do so makes me respect him more as a character.


Yukinoshita Yukino:


The cool, strong, levelheaded, and stubborn girl seen in the first season has quite a dramatic change in character in the second season. With her views on Hachiman's actions and ideas as unacceptable, the two come into odds in a very serious manner, which, at many times, threatened to break apart the club. Yukino makes it very clear during Hachiman's "confession" in EP 2. that she does not approve of his actions, yet she cannot articulate why she thinks that way. I think through the various bonds that Yukino has created with both Hachiman and Yui, she has started to care for both of them, which causes her to feel hurt when she sees Hachiman's self abuse. When Hachiman talks about the failures of his actions and his goal to reach something "genuine", Yukino backs off in shock. In the next episodes, her character starts to warm a bit, and she becomes more "dependent" on Hachiman (I used dependent here because "trust" is questioned by her sister Haruno in the later episodes, and to me I think that needs a bit more clarification to fully understand).


Yuigahama Yui:


Yui serves as the "glue" between Hachiman and Yukino with her light-hearted "nice girl" personality. Her character is sort of the opposite of Yukino and Hachiman, with her already having many friends at school and being quite popular among those that know her. However, because she is seen as the "nice girl", she actually feels quite distant from the other two. In addition, the fact that she is seen as a "nice girl" makes that a facade for her. The other characters, even the analytical Hachiman, did not see until the very end until she gave him the cookies and said that she will take everything because that is what she wants. I had a hard time analysing Yui's character in the last episode, because she never gave a specific answer to what she wanted (which Hachiman noted), so I can curious to find out what she meant.


Iroha Isshiki:


The newly introduced character of this season who becomes the student council president. Seemingly a platonic character, she is actually a very cunning and dynamic girl.  From my perspective she hides her true personality in order to prevent herself from being seen in bad light by other people, as she holds her reputation quite high. However, after listening to Hachiman's "genuine" speech, she strives to change herself. This is exemplified in her confession to Hayato and her rejection, as the Hachiman's words gives her the strength to toss aside her facade, and aim for what she wants.


Overall:


I would definitely recommend it as it was my personal favourite series of Spring 2015. With unique dialogue and characterisation, this show deserves the numerous accolades that it gets from viewers.  It is a 9/10 series for me. Thank you so much for reading, and if possible please give me some constructive suggestions so that I may improve the next time I write. I hope you have a wonderful day wherever you are!

Now we'll begin with character, honestly I was annoyed by 2 characters which I really really liked from season 1. Firstly, Yukinoshita Yukino. The title says this contain spoilers but it's only if I accidentally spoil it, as much as I can, I will try not to. Secondly would be none other that Yukinoshita Haruno, the more hotter version of her younger sister. Her character in season 1 was purely mentor-typed and comedy relief, but somehow in this season, she shifted into like a semi-antagonistic villain who can make anyone into her enemy anytime.

Right... for me, this anime is an absolute masterpiece. It is something that I never imagined would ever exist. I know some people dislike this anime. I know some people even hate this anime. But I think I know the reason why. I'll come to that later. This anime tackles issues that does exist in our current high school generation(believe me... I know). 
Yukinoshita Yukino... if you're a younger sibling and you're always compared to your older and more popular and more successful sibling... it does feel bad. In most cases, if you have close friends... at least you'll have them to treat you asan individual. However in Yukino's case, she's a loner... then obviously she finds Hachiman and Yui where her life takes a dramatic turn. 


On the other hand, Yuigahama Yui... admit it... there are many who change themselves just to be accepted. And once they are accepted, they can't change back as it will cost them their popularity. Yui goes along with everything Yumiko says and does just so at the end of the day, she can be friends with someone as popular as her to gain popularity as well. Trust me, more people exist in today's world than you think who are just like Yui. 


And then we have Hikigaya Hachiman... my all time favourite character... not only in anime but in all fictions. And let me tell you... I've watched/read most popular fictions/anime. He deserves so much respect as a character. Admit it, if you're a loner... you develop a certain mindset towards society. But in most cases... if not all cases, you don't express that mindset because that just makes everything worse for you. Hachiman on the other hand, isn't scared. He stays true to who he is and understands the conventions of society better than anyone else. Most loners would half the first half of Hachiman's character i.e. having a certain mindset towards society. However not many... if any loners can be like Hachiman. In that way, he is truly an inspiration.


Yes I'll admit that the whole setting and some other characters and some other things are sort of cliche and not realistic like the main characters. However if you're able to ignore that just like me then you'll find this anime amazing. In other words, this is a real-life show school show that is still an anime. Another way to sum it up would be that it's the closest thing you can get to a realistic school anime whilst still being entertaining. The only thing that can beat this anime if someone does something similar but instead they make the setting and other things more realistic. All whilst still making it entertaining to watch.


Now to why some people hate this. In my opinion, you can only like this anime if you understand it fully. Some people would see the name 'My Teen Romantic Comedy SNAFU' and think to themselves that it would be just a romantic comedy for them to watch without using their brain too much. These people try not using their brain and so they think to themselves "wtf was that". The other reason that some people might dislike this is maybe because they aren't too aware of how things truly are in the current generation. These people could either be the really popular school children who don't know how much a loner is socially smarter than them so they would find it annoying at how the loner disrespects the popularity created in school. Or these people could be the older people who have a mentality set towards their days in high school instead of the modern high school. This makes them say stuff such as 'this anime is just trying to be too philosophical' or 'it's boring' or 'nothing really happens throughout the anime' and so on when at the end of the day, it's a very entertaining and helpful portrayal of high-school society of TODAY... not earlier.

YAHELLO!!! I saw the first season of this anime and really enjoyed it and was hoping for a second season, and to see the continuation of the story. I also really loved the dynamic between Hikigaya and Yukinon, and I just really liked the character Hikigaya. He was the antithesis to most other main characters of romance anime and I really liked that.  However I feel that the second season, in my opinion, declined in quality. Spoilers ahead of this point, be aware. Hikigaya became a lot more emotional and lost his overall character development that was created in the first season. He wentfrom being antisocial, never shows any emotion type of guy to a guy that openly cries and can't take being alone anymore. I know this changed because of his growing relationships with Yui and Yukinon but to me it seemed like his character completely changed from how he was in the first season. Also Yukinon's character completely changed from the first season to the second. She went from being a strong, didn't take shit from anyone type character to a very emotional and easily swayed by Haru's words and actions. Haru uses loaded language and I was very confused by it.  Yui remained pretty constant from season to season so I enjoyed that. I also didn't understand what was happening in the story from the middle of the season onward. All of their problems were all confusing and none of their problems seemed significant. The reason I didn't enjoy this season as much as the last season is because of the ending. This is a romance anime and so I hoped that Hikigaya would end up with one of the girls. (Team Iroha). However that didn't happen, nothing really happened at all. Overall though I did enjoy it, just not as much as the first season, and I also thought it was a lot more confusing. LASTLY, that greeting "yahello" was annoying as hell and they said it so much...

Being new to the whole Anime environment and storytelling, I want to state that this is what I felt watching this show, and not me telling you guys that this show is bad. It's my opinion and nothing more.
This show is definitely for people who find Hiki, Yui or Yukinoshita reliving things from your time in school. It’s a snail-progressed story-driven idea about how you learn to understand yourself and put trust into others eventually making friends. Though this series is tagged with drama, comedy, and romance it's almost far from it. The confrontations and drama are not as you'd expect from a slice oflife series, small-romance indeed, but nothing major or anything for you to care about since it's not regarding the characters you're following throughout the series. The comedy in this show? Yeah, it's mostly set in the first season. Season 2 is a steep mountainside that lets you end up in the bottom furious to the point where every episode works as a (1 step forward, 3 steps back ) show. This show is not meant to end happily regardless since the 3 protagonist never gets to the root of (!their!) problem. They don't talk about it with each other, after continuously helping other students helping or fixing their problems. They end up as it started, Hiki and Yukinoshita rotting whilst savoring their pride. Oh and Yui not wanting to let go of them, their club and their "friendship"


Other than that its a bland story dwelling on the "lonely, shy, unpopular, not-understood" guy or girl, that needs to learn to navigate socially by attending meetings in a volunteer club where a random request from fellow students is to be completed. To guide them is a teacher that herself are facing problems finding anyone to marry her basically struggling socially as well.  She is trying to help Hiki and Yukinoshita, by understanding feelings and showing them, learning them to be vulnerable and that its okay to feel and express. Most importantly to ask for help.


I don't get this series since I can't see myself or any similarities in these characters nor the scenarios they're going through. It's downright depressing, where nothing but the very club they're part of is the only functional thing in this series, where completion exists and is the goal. 


My overall score 3/10 - poor


I don't hate this show for not replicating my time in school, I'm not forcing or anticipating that every slice of life anime would, and I'm not anticipating that any of the animes I'm watching needs to awaken some kind of thing I can relate to, for me to rate it higher than what've done to Yahari Ore no. But this one for me is indeed sad to a whole new point. I'm sorry this did not favor my tastes after watching other long reviews that by quickly reading them shares common ground with the watcher. it sure seems that many found their holy grail within this one. I'm sad I didn't

The second season of Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Comedy wa Machigatteiru (referred to from here on as just "Love Comedy" for brevity's sake) was absolutely worth watching. While I don't think it's as good as the first season, (by kind of a wide margin...) there are a few moments scattered throughout that struck me hard enough to make me glad that I saw it. The show has some pretty glaring issues that make it hard to recommend to anyone else wholeheartedly, but there's still so much to like about it.
One of my favorite things about "Love Comedy" is that it's a show about smalltragedies. The stakes of any given situation presented in the show are pretty low in the grand scheme of things - nobody's lives are going to be ruined if the school festival for one year isn't impressive, or the cookies they make don't taste good. But "Love Comedy" is very deliberately not focused on the "big picture" that puts those kinds of things in perspective. It's focused on the things that matter to us in spite of their insignificance. 


"Love Comedy" presents those moments with the weight of genuine tragedy. I know that makes it sound like it's melodramatic, and it is, but... it's believably melodramatic. The show's drama comes from the way people feel, not the things that happen to them, so it doesn't matter how small the stakes are. The climactic moments of the series don't happen when a conflict is reaching a breaking point; they come when a character is reaching a breaking point. So yeah, it's melodramatic, but it's melodramatic because human beings are kinda melodramatic.


The show is clearly more interested in the small details more than it is in the grand scheme of things, which makes the style of writing in the second season feel at-odds with the story it wants to tell. Everything the characters say to each other is suddenly extremely vague; they say all these grand-sounding things that don't seem to actually mean anything when you analyze them. In a show focused on small conflicts, it's strange that all of the dialogue expresses emotion in a way that only makes sense if you look at the overall tone of the writing rather than the words themselves.


That's not to say it's all bad. There is a line in the fourth episode that resonated so strongly with me that I had to pause the show so I could give it time to sink in. It's a line that can only come out of something this small-scale; it's a moment that wouldn't be important to show if the conflict were any larger. It's a one-sided realization that is happening only for one person, and is more meaningful because everyone around the person realizing it is totally oblivious to it. It's a conflict that feels resolved because the character simply becomes comfortable with the fact that it's not really going to be resolved.


Unfortunately, most of the rest of the season fails to hit that high-water mark. The stakes are gradually raised over the course of the season, and that small moment of self-reflection doesn't really happen again. There are bigger moments of self-reflection, sure, but they don't manage to feel as meaningful as the smaller ones do. And the writing continues to be vague in a way that makes the relatively simple plot actually hard to follow. There are times when it feels like nothing's happening and the characters are just talking in circles and saying nothing. Which is ironic, considering how there is an entire arc of the second season criticizing that style of self-important, circular talk.


I think I could look past the cryptic dialogue and frustratingly rising stakes if either of those actually paid off in any meaningful way. Instead, the series seems to build up to something big, reaches a climax of sorts, then has four episodes of things seeming to settle into place before jumping out with another big climax at the very end. And I mean the VERY end. This season ends on an incredibly unsatisfying cliffhanger that would be more forgivable if there were more episodes to come. And even then, the plot this cliffhanger sets up points in a direction I'm just not all that interested in seeing play out. 


The last glaring issue I have with the second season of "Love Comedy"is that there's really not that much comedy in it anymore. The first season had frequent moments of levity that helped relieve some of the tension and put the conflicts back into perspective. The second season takes the occasional jab at humor, but that mostly consists of the characters repeating some "quirky" behavior or dialogue over and over. It's always the same joke, they just tell it multiple times. This season severely lacks anything to contrast its melodrama against, which actually serves to make it feel less real and grounded overall. 


The second season of "Love Comedy" has issues. The dialogue is vague and hard to parse the meaning of, the comedy is completely missing, and it all builds to a moment it never even attempts to pay off. All that said, I struggle to score it anything lower than a seven because the high moments were so important to me, and because it does still carry some of the spirit of the first season with it. It probably deserves a little lower, but I'm a sentimental person, and this is a very sentimental series, so I personally liked it quite a bit in spite of its issues. It's probably worth watching if you liked the first season, but don't expect it to surpass it any way.

This is a spoiler free Review
I am...confused. I watched through the first season just to get to the "Oh so fabulous and wonderful" Second season. 8 episodes in, and I keep repeated finding myself asking the questions: Why? Why is she crying? Why is she so mad? Why is HE crying? What is going on? Who is this person? What does that even mean? What the fuck did he even do to trigger her?
I ask these questions to myself about 5 times in each episode. I just don't understand how what they say to each other makes sense, sometimes I even pause the anime tryingto interpret what they say, but after doing that a couple of times, I stopped and I know that Animes like these shouldn't be interpreted.


Yes, many of my friends who enjoyed this anime tells me, don't question the motives or the plot, just watch it and let the drama come to me. How the hell am I supposed to enjoy the drama when I spend half the episode wondering what the fuck happened in the last episode for this episode to make this less sense. This anime needs to be interpreted to be fully enjoyed, however, there isn't enough dialogue to fully let the audience know what the fuck is going on. It might be because I watched it in subbed, but I haven't had a problem with Kissanime's subs that much.


This anime is very like 5 Centimeters per Second, where the plot makes sense and the audience knows where you're trying to go with the plot. But there not enough dialogue for the audience, and they are left confused rather than seeing the motives behind what the characters feel and say.


Specifics:

Story: Is a 5, it very normal and somewhat boring, just reading the synopsis makes me not want to watch this anime.


Art: It is very solid, it is an 8 because I feel like there surprising a lot of beautiful animation clips in an anime that doesn't really have any actions.


Sound: Is an 8, makes a story a little better, but I tend to like music from all animes, so it might be a little biased.


Characters: If there is any reason to watch this show, it is simply to watch the complexity and general emotions that the characters feel. The main protagonist is what I would call a four-dimensional character, not only does he have a motive, which makes a character three dimensional, but he actually tells you a motive but hides the real motive away from everyone, including the audience, including even himself. Almost every character, from the sensei to Kaori to Komachi, they are all multi-dimensional. 10/10


Enjoyment: 5, maybe even lower, I was just triggered half the time I was watching.


Overall: 6/10 I wouldn't really recommend this to anyone, but hey if you like to interpret and analyze classic Japanese visual Literature, be my guest.

Fine if it were a new series, failure as a sequel.
There's two big problems I have with this sequel and one minor problem. Let's start with the minor one.
Entire art style changed. Lots of bloom everywhere for no reason. It's like watching a sequel to a video game, if you know what I mean. Character art remained the same with the exception of a few key characters. The main male character had a minor makeover which is totally okay but other characters started suffering from sameface syndrome and there was a time in the anime where I wasn't sure who a character was and wasin doubt between 3 different characters with one of them being a main heroine. Obviously a very bad direction for the art but it did get a bit better towards the end.


Now, one of the big problems - The character of the previously mentioned main heroine was completely changed. Used to be a witty and cold girl but in this season was presented as spineless and seemingly on the verge of crying all the time. Why this direction was taken, I will probably forever fail to comprehend.


The last problem is the story itself. A major conflict arose from a main character doing something bold that solved the problem pretty much perfectly and in addition the other side was basically in on it. This action, however, requited harsh criticism from the other main characters. I was completely dumbfounded at this point and failed to understand what all the fuss is about. This was nothing out of the ordinary for the character and as previously mentioned, worked as a solution. This was also one of the only cool solution, which the character was known for in the previous season, that was used. The rest of the season, the character seemed rather useless.

Much of the emotional dialogue between the three main characters was utterly incomprehensible and made little sense. I really don't understand where they were going with this and this more than foolish plot ruined the anime for me.


Not all is lost, however, the Iroha x Hachiman scenes were pretty good. :)

But other than that, major disappointment and I don't understand the high scores.

I'll be continuing the review from the first season so if there's something that you don't understand, take a look at the previous review I made for the first season. 
Well.. after that different kind of experience from season one, I was hoping I could get more out of this one but sad to say that I was kind of disappointed. Same old stuff I guess and same old story progression. Well.. I hope that no one felt the same as I did watching this show. The fact that I feel this way is because I kind of have a similar situation with the maincharacter back in grade school. I was always left out and unnoticed and all I could do that time was think. Though bitter as life may be, I try to enjoy it because I know that I can't keep sulking for the rest of my life and I'm sure time will come when things might turn the right way. The main character here however, is as hopeless as he can get. Though not your usual dense main characters from other series, this one is sensitive about it though he pretends or wishes to be dense about the issue in the title. The rollercoaster of emotions from the first season happened to make its way into the second one too so there's still some of that. The story is most likely just a continuation of the first season because the first episode picked up where it left off. The art style has changed because the series switched studios and now I don't know if the art has improved but however the animation has become more fluid and the backgrounds are way better this time. The opening sequence fit the show better than the first season's. The background music seemed to have improved also. The characters are still the same though developed maybe just a bit. I think the only thing that stands out is that they look a bit different. I can't say I enjoyed this season that much in fact, I was somewhat bored and disappointed that it was just a repetition of the first season but with a different aspect. Though it stirred up a lot of emotions and the drama seem a bit heavier, I honestly wasn't able to relate at all. The ending is somewhat reasonable but I think it was left by a cliffhanger there. I don't know if I can handle another season of this and I'm sure as heck not gonna read the manga because I think that this series wasn't really for me. Still, I'm glad I finished this anime and maybe I'll think about recommending this to people who haven't seen it yet. I gave this decent anime a decent rating and I think that's what it deserves.

This anime is hard to depict in a few words. For me to summarize it shortly i would say it is a break-down of social hierarchy and social standards. The greatness of having friends or being a loner. Hikigaya in the first season has not resolved whether these two girls surrounding him are pleasant or unfortunate. In this season he has come to the conclusion that these people are great people. The 2nd Season starts off where the first one ended with Hikigaya hated as he does not realize the consequences of his self-sacrifice. Ifeel like they take this at the correct speed and do not just rush for him to think that he matters. He does this by realising his flaws and  This 2nd Season focuses more on genuine friendships and relations with other than the first. As quoted by Hikigaya "The things handed to you on a silver plate are never genuine, and never everlasting". This explores the sociological idea of relationships are built over time and cannot be gained instantly. Friendships on Commercial Society: Eighteen-Century Social Theory and Modern Sociology by Allan Silver says "commercial society sharply distinguishes self-interested from sympathetic relations and is therefore necessary for the spread of personal relations based on sympathy and sentiment". Ok, ok you might be a bit confused but what this article is trying to say is that social interactions can be categorized into : Sympathetic or Self-interested. What this means is that you are either trying to get something out of the relationship or you are speaking to someone of lower class and you are using 'sympathy' (as used in this article). This is showcased in Oregairu with their depictions of social hierarchy. It can also be interpreted as challenging this view as one of the main themes of this season is Hikigaya's desire for 'something genuine'. You could interpret this as wanting friendship that is not influenced by social hierarchy. You could also say this is achieved by the end of the season. One thing i have not talked about is the introduction of Iroha the new 'potential love interest' but with this anime I saw that this was going nowhere. She adds some diversity to cast and is also a very real character as she might seem cunning and deceiving but she truly is a good girl.\n

I seriously struggled to finish this anime. Half way through it I wanted to drop it but kept watching.
The pacing is terrible. After 13 episodes I feel like nothing happened and wasted a few hours of my life. Show tries way too hard to be philosophical or make it seem like there's always tension but fails miserably because like I said nothing really happens. This series could have worked a lot more as a standalone 13 episodes show, 24+ episodes plus a possible 3rd season/ovas is just too much.
I don't think there's anything else to add since people watching a sequel already knows what's about.imo it's not a terrible show in any way but personally it was a borefest and doubt I'm coming back for a next season.\n\n
Overall I rate 7/10 mainly because of the good animation and yanaginagi's opening

These days, I rarely do anime reviews, but when I do, it's for a "Must Watch!" type of story. 
When you learn a lesson from a story, it is rare for that lesson to actually change your life/become applicable to the real world. Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Comedy wa Machigatteiru Zoku did a great job at emphasizing the fact that it's impossible to understand other people 100%. The story of this anime is meant to be confusing, not in the sense that it has plot holes, but rather that the meaning is so implicitly well-hidden, that the viewer has to decipher each episode, maybeeven rewatch them because this anime is just that deep. Is youth a lie? What is genuine? I highly recommend this anime, especially for teenagers as they try to find themselves. The main character, Hikigaya Hachiman, is quite possibly the most relatable anime character there is. 


Story= 10/10 (Outstanding). It is very rare to find a story that is as well-written as this one. On the surface, this anime may appear like any Rom-Com or Harem story, but I highly advise you to think otherwise and be prepared for anything.


Art- 10/10 (Outstanding). As this 2nd season is made by a different studios than the 1st season, the visuals have been vastly improved, and, dare I say that this might be among the top 5 best-looking anime ever. 


Sound- 10/10 (Outstanding). Music speaks for itself, as it can be a powerful emotional tool that is difficult to explain. 


Character- 9/10 (Great). There is one questionable line in episode 8 that Yukinoshita Yukino said that left me confused. Other than that, the characters are very diverse in terms of their social situations ranging from cynical or cold loners like Hikigaya and Yukinoshita to the "fake" or "superficial" extroverted Hayama Hayato to the adults that give our two main characters some advise when they need it such as Hiratsuka Sensei. All in all, the cast of OreGairu is very entertaining and they always leave me with a "What's going to happen next?!" vibe, a rare feeling that very few anime actually are capable of. 


Enjoyment- 10/10 (Outstanding). While there are comedic situations involving our favorite loner, there are also moments of tension between characters; this anime made me enjoy deciphering the deeply encrypted story in a way that no other story could. 


Overall score= 9/10 (Great). 


Now, can we please get a season 3 already?

Hey folks, this will be a review for Yahari Ore no Seishun Love Comedy wa Machigatteiru. Zoku. "I want something genuine", ...... "I don't understand". These two quotes can summarize the entire second season.
The story picks up right after the first season. A new request is made to the volunteer club, which is still operated by our three main characters. This request is the catalyst for a 13 episode plunge into a pool of forced, petty, and rather pseudo intellectual drama.
I don't want to come off as a snob, however anime drama tends to lean this direction a lot. Whether you agreed or disagreed withstatements or actions made in the first season it didn't really matter. The show never tried to preach or to seem sophisticated. This season however is filled with dialogue and weighty scenes with no substance at all. To top that off they just vomit it at you. There isn't a break in the drama and it comes from all angles. Making it feel like the story was either rushed, or non existent. We even end on a cliff hangar.


The art and sound are both fantastic.


The characters are the driving force of the show, and as such are given and equally low score. Each character changes, almost to their exact opposite of what they were in the first season. We get a new character who was actually rather enjoyable. Aside from her however we lose a great character in Hachiman as he barely does anything except be the drama thorn. Yukino's personality becomes that of a rag doll for the other characters to rip and tear at. Yui doesn't change much until the end of the show when she suddenly grows large and hairy balls. In fact this season its hard to call our main characters the main characters. Iroha steals most of the time and has the most depth and interest.


The first time I watched this show, I was torn. Its hard to not like a second season of a show that you love. However after watching it again, this season was really terrible. It felt tailor made for the Jaden Smiths of the world to enjoy and to feel smug about as they pretended to follow along with it. All of the drama revolved around poorly constructed sequences and lack of communication. The real hard hitting moments like the romance, or the family troubles of Yukino are hinted at but not followed up on. Maybe it was actually good, and like Hachiman I forced my own ideals onto the show and when that was changed I felt betrayed. Though I doubt that to be the case.

After the first season, I expected, if nothing else, more of the same. An enjoyable show that was funny, witty, and occasionally harsh. A sequel to a show that felt like it stepped outside of the expectations of the "love comedy" shows that we've come to know, love, or loathe.
This, on the other hand, felt like a combination of a standard love drama and something that just wasn't really that good. It dragged on for half of it, and its message just wasn't clear a lot of the time either. While the point of the show is that its characters are "real," or so somesay, when there are points where the love interests are made out to be completely lacking in empathy or common sense multiple times over, yet the narrative insists they are in the right, we have a problem.


The first bout of drama was the result of one such event. One love interest encourages the protagonist to take action, knowing full well what he's like. She says she's relying on him. He takes action in the way he does, and she proceeds to tell him she hates how he does things and leave. This is followed by the other love interest telling him to think of the feelings of others (a tad hypocritical really) and also leaving, and then half of the show is spent slowly dealing with the fallout. 


Whereas the first season made sharp commentary, this one chooses to be pointlessly and annoyingly vague far too often, and avoids addressing what's going on too much of the time, leaving viewers to wonder what any of the characters are talking about or feeling more often than a show has any right doing, much less one that's following up this one's first season.


The worst part of it is when it's not dragging out and forcing this drama is that the cast of characters really can be a breath of fresh air - with the exception of the main heroine and the drama the author insists on packaging her with and forcing on us, that is. I can't help but think the story would be much, much stronger if it could be written without the fear of cancellation, as many Japanese works so clearly are, because that love triangle and tease to keep begging readers and viewers to keep coming back could be scrapped for something more focused and genuine.


And that's pretty ironic when you think about it.


The core problem of Oregairu that rears its head in the second season over and over again is that it's trying to do two things simultaneously that conflict a lot with each other. The first is that it's trying to have a flawed, human protagonist that is coming to terms with his issues and damages. It's showing us a person who is cynical and who doesn't understand and can't work with people, but is getting there.


The second thing is that it's still trying to abide by a lot of stereotypes of stories within this genre/setting. In the end, the narrative is set up so that this protagonist can still be a hero and save these girls and be there for them. In a way, it's pandering to the mindset of the viewer/reader that wants these girls to be their "waifus" in this respect. It's not inherently a bad thing to do that, but as it's presented, it conflicts with the first thing it's trying to do somewhat.


For a lot of the show, the protagonist himself is clearly someone in need of helping. Towards the end of this season, a point is reached where the protagonist owns up to how he's done a lot of wrong and comes asking for help. 


This results in a reminder of how another character also needs saving, some drama, and eventually what seems like a resolution. In itself, this would have been a good way to close the series - but that's not how things work. Despite the show's commentary on the status quo, these types of shows are all ABOUT the status quo, it seems.


Immediately after this event, the next episode opens with "that was so embarrassing I want to die" from the protagonist, and the genuineness of that resolution is called into question throughout the rest of the season and never even really resolved. This is the third problem with it. Unlike the first season, this one seemed very intent on getting viewers more invested in the source material than just being a standalone product, and it shows.


All in all, this leaves something that can very easily leave viewers unsatisfied. It does create a "real" seeming story, but the show doesn't pace these things nearly well enough for it to be effective - and that's assuming this story would work if paced well to begin with.
